dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Jake?! No answer. He races up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: INT JAKE'S ROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: Tom SMACKS open the door to Jake's room and flicks on the lights. In Jake's bed, the covers are pulled back, the sh are rumpled. But Jake Js gone. Tom races out. Still staring at that empty bed, we can he other doors in the house being thrown open, lights being switched on, and Tom's outraged voice calling out for his

dialogues.speaker: EXT STREET NIGHT
dialogues.text: Maggie comes hurrying up the steps of the porch just as t front door flies open.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: What the hell is the-

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: She took him.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: What?!

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Oh, my God! She bounds up the steps, calling out for Jake.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: She can't be that far! He runs to the corner, desperate, and looks up and down t street in both directions. There are a lot of people out, could be anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He turns, looks up and down the side street. Nothing in t first direction, but when he looks the other way, he hear faint BUZZING sound in the distance. He doesn't hesitate, just takes off toward it.

dialogues.speaker: TWO BLOCKS AHEAD,
dialogues.text: Tom is running as hard as he can. He stops, abruptly. The buzzing sound is gone. He looks to his right. Behind a wa there is a large parking lot filled with buses. He turns around. A dull white glow comes from the windows the place on the corner. He looks up, at the sign. It's a Greyhound bus station. Tom hurries back toward it, reaching the door just as Mag comes running up from the opposite direction.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Wait right here, keep your eyes open! He opens the door and goes inside.

dialogues.speaker: INT BUS STATION NIGHT
dialogues.text: Tom steps into the station, still breathing hard. The BUZ sound returns. But from where? Is it in his mind this tim or really here, in the bus station? The place is empty except for one person, sitting on a wo bench with their back to him, near the departure doors. T walks slowly across the place to the figure. It's Dorothy As he draws closer, he sees Jake's face, over Dorothy's shoulder. Jake's eyes are open, and he's staring up at th ceiling. Tom follows his son's gaze. Jake is staring up at the lig the old-style fluorescent tubes that give the place its cancerous look. The tubes BUZZ loudly. It's the sound Tom been hearing. Jake sees his father and smiles. Tom puts a finger to his lips -- "Shhhh." Jake yawns, closes his eyes, and drops h head onto Dorothy's shoulder. He goes back to sleep. Tom walks slowly around the end of the bench. Dorothy is SINGING softly, an old nursery rhyme. She looks up suddenly and sees Tom. She starts to jerk to feet. Tom puts a hand out -- take it easy. Dorothy sits back, caught. Tom steps closer to her, carefully. He hold both his hands out, palms up. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Give him to me. She shakes her head no. Outside, a SIREN WHINES and a pol car flashes past the window, its red lights spinning. The both hear it and glance over, then look back at each othe Tom raises an eyebrow. She knows what he means. TOM (cont'd) Give him to me, Dorothy. Trembling, Dorothy reaches out, Jake in her arms. Tom gen takes the boy from her and holds him tight. The front door flies open and Maggie races inside. Tom gi Jake over to her.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (half asleep) Oh, hi, Mommy. She's relieved, but livid.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (to Dorothy) What the hell is the matter with you?! Dorothy jumps to her feet and races through the door that leads to the back, where the buses leave from.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (to Maggie) Take him home! I'll be there as soon as I can! He runs after Dorothy.

dialogues.speaker: EXT PARKING LOT NIGHT
dialogues.text: Dorothy races out of the bus station and into the forest parked buses. Tom comes out a few seconds later, giving chase. Dorothy cuts between two parked buses -- -- and is nearly hit by a third that's just arriving. Its horn BLARES as she trips and falls to the ground, the bus missing as it ROARS past her. Tom reaches her. Dorothy writhes on the ground, sobbing, raking her hands through the gravel, hysterical. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Sit up. Sit up, I want to talk to you. She manages to drag herself into a sitting position. She shoves back, against the wheel of a bus. Beyond them, the that nearly hit her stops on the far side of the lot. Dorothy is quivering, still crying. Tom squats in front o her, a few feet away. TOM (cant' d) Why were you taking my son?

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: Go away.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Do you want me to call the police? (shakes her head no) Then tell me why you took him.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: He isn't safe in your house.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Why do you say that?

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: He told me! He told me so! The DRIVER of the bus that nearly hit her is out of his b now. He SHOUTS at them from the other side of the lot.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Jake said that? (she nods) What else did he say?

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: Nothing. I was sitting there, I was watching him sleep, I was just watching him, like I'm supposed to, and... and he sat up in bed, he looked right at me, and he said "I'm not safe in this house." Two times, he said it, and then he went back to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Where were you taking him? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: California. To my father's house. My real father, not -- (like poison on her tongue) -- Duane. Jake would be safe at my father's house, we'd both be safe there.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: You too? (she nods) Why aren't you safe here? She doesn't answer. The Driver is coming over to them, st SHOUTING. TOM (cont' d) Dorothy? Dorothy, why aren't you safe here? The Driver is still closer. Frightened, Dorothy gets up, run again. Tom grabs her. TOM (coat' d) Hey, wait a sec- As his hands close around her arms --

dialogues.speaker: AN IMAGE
dialogues.text: flashes through his mind. A MAN'S FACE, sweaty and unshav leers over us, too close.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE PARKING LOT,
dialogues.text: Tom abruptly pulls back from Dorothy. He is enraged.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Who is he?! She just looks at him, frightened. He shakes her, violent TOM (cont' d)

dialogues.speaker: INT DOROTHY'S HOUSE NIGHT
dialogues.text: DUANE, fortyish, slouches on a sofa, watching Moe hit Cur with a rake. Duane's drinking bourbon. In his defense, he using a glass. Duane's face is the one Tom just saw in th image in his mind. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Duane hears the front door open and close.

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: You're early. Your mom's still at work. Hey, do you know if she bought any more who the fuck are you? Tom is storming across the room toward him. DUANE (cant' d) Hey hey hey hey HEY! Tom already has Duane by the collar. He wrenches him to h feet. DUANE (cont' d)

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Are you Duane?

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: Who?! I don't even know who you're- Duane looks over Tom's shoulder. Dorothy is standing in t doorway, frightened. DUANE (cont' d) Dorothy, who the fuck is this guy?! Tom hurls Duane across the coffee table, knocking over Du bong. Duane hits the floor hard. He starts fumbling in hi pocket, but Tom is on him, ripping him to his feet again.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: She's a little girl, you son of a bitch! She' s fifteen years old, and you fucked her!? What the hell is the matter with you?! YOU DON'T DO SHIT

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: Look, man, I don't know who you are or what she told you, but- Tom hurls Duane across the room. He SMASHES into a bookca breaking the glass shelves and knocking a bunch of pictur and knickknacks to the ground. Duane SCREAMS, tries to ro away to escape Tom, but Tom picks him up by the back of h collar and his belt, like a dog. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GET OUT
dialogues.text: He hurls Duane toward the stairs. Duane CRUNCHES down har Before he can get up, Tom hauls him to his feet and hurls furthe: up. He's kicking Duane's ass up the stairs. At the +,)ttom, Dorothy watches, her hands over her mouth She's thrilled.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE TOP OF THE STAIRS,
dialogues.text: Duane lands, a few feet ahead of Tom. This time he's got second or two, and he manages to dig the butterfly knife was groping for out of his pocket. He whips it around, opening it, but Tom is fast and crazy rage, he just grabs the thing by the blade and rips it aw from Duane. Blood flows over Tom's knuckles as he tighten his grip on the knife. He twists it around, holding it by butt. There's madness in Tom's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (wielding the knife) You got ten minutes. Pack your shit. You don't leave a note, you don't try to call, and if you ever, ever come back here again, I'll know, I'll find you, and I'll stick this so far into you they'll never get it out. You got it? Duane nods, terrified.

dialogues.speaker: DOWN IN THE LIVING ROOM,
dialogues.text: Dorothy sits on her hands at the edge of the sofa, waitin nervously. Tom comes down the stairs. He folds the knife, uncertainly, never handled one of these things before. He shoves it in his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I'll stay until he's gone. Upstairs, dresser drawers SLAM, Duane CURSES. He's packin TOM (cont' d) Shouldn't be long.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: You're bleeding. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She hurries into the kitchen. Tom looks around, at the me he's made. He's embarrassed, frightened by his own rage. Dorothy comes back with a dish towel. She takes Tom's han wipes the blood away and wraps the towel around it. DOROTHY (cont' d) Than : you. He starts to pick up the things that were knocked off the bookcase.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Tell your mother I'll pay for this.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: It's okay. He picks up a framed photograph. Broken glass falls out o the frame as he turns it over. Tom freezes. DOROTHY (cont'd) What's the matter? Tom just stares at the picture. DOROTHY (cont' d) What? Tom turns the picture around to show Dorothy. The woman i the picture is about eighteen or nineteen, bears a faint resemblance to Dorothy -- -- and is the same woman he saw in his living room. DOROTHY (coast' d) Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Who is this woman?

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: My sister.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Did she have a black dress, kind of a diamond pattern on it?

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: She wore a lot of bracelets, those thick ones, different colors, all up and down her arms?

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: Yeah, all t2;+ time, she probably still does. How d., you know that? Upstairs, there is a tremendous SLAM as a closet door clo and Duane SHOUTS. DUANE (o.s.)

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Where is she?

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Can I talk to her?

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: She ran away. About six months ago.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Where did she go?

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: I don't know! She don't write or nothin'. Tom looks down at the photograph again.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: What's your sister's name, Dorothy?

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: Samantha.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT TOM i MAGGIE'S HOUSE NIGHT The red light glows on the baby monitor, and Jake's breat can be heard from in his bedroom. Tom and Maggie sit on t couch in their living room, the nonitor beside them, just light on. He has his arms arounc' her, holding her tight. hand is bandaged. They're shaker..

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Samantha?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: That's what she said.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Where have I heard that name before?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Dorothy said she ran away about six months ago.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: But she could still be around! Hiding or something. I mean, she could have actually been here when you saw her!

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: If she was, she's very quick getting in and out of a room.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Where was she? When you saw her, where was she exactly?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: On the cushion right next to you. Maggie looks down at the empty half of the couch, freaked She pulls in closer to him.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: What was it like? At the game, I mean, how did you know about Jake? Did you see anything?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: It's hard to explain. I just got this -- feeling.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Like when I was drowning? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: A little bit. But a hundred times stronger.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Does it hurt when it happens?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Like you wouldn't believe. Fecls like my brain is tearing in half.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: God, Tommy, what's the matter with you?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Why do you assume it's bad? Maybe this is a good thing.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: If your brain is tearing in half?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I told you there was somethin' in me. Maybe it's comin' out.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I like it better in.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Just roll with it. What's the worst that can happen?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You'll go insane. Kill yourself. Kill me and Jake first.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Well, yeah, that...

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I want you to go see my cousin Elizabeth. Make sure there's nothing wrong. Just tell her about the headaches, that's all she needs to know, you don't have to bring up the other stuff. Suddenly, he smiles. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Hey, know what? (she looks at him) It is a girl. She furrows her brow, "how do you know?", then follows hi gaze down to her belly, where his hand is resting.

dialogues.speaker: INT HOSPITAL CORRIDOR DAY
dialogues.text: Tom, dressed in a patient's gown, walks down a hospital corridor with DR. ELIZABETH NOONAN, fortyish. Elizabeth m notes on a clipboard, walking and talking fast, all busin Elizabeth does not have the human touch.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Do you have any metal plates in your skull?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Any shrapnel lodged anywhere in your body?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: No cardiac pacemaker, I assume -- iron filings near your eyes?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: You don't work with sheet metal, do you?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Left here. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They turn down another corridor. ELIZABETH (cont' d) Do you have an inner ear transplant?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Aneurism clips in your brain?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: No thanks.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Do you suffer from claustrophobia?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Only in, like, really small spaces. (she looks at him, straight

dialogues.speaker: FACED
dialogues.text: You have a great sense of humor.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Right, then jog left. They do.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Do we really gotta do this?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: You've had no head trauma, no serious viral infections you can recall, you haven't been out of the country, you're not a drug user, you have no history of migraines... I suppose I could open up your skull in the operating room and then decide what to do, but I'd rather take a few pictures first, wouldn't you? She pushes through a set of double doors.

dialogues.speaker: INT MRI ROOM DAY
dialogues.text: The MRI machine is a long tunnel with a body slab stickin obscenely, like a tongue. TWO NURSES stand on either side it. One wall of the room is glass, behind the glass are t TECHNICIANS -- and Maggie, who waves supportively. Tom swallows. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: How's it work? Elizabeth goes to a computer terminal and types in some commands.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: It creates an electromagnetic field thirty thousand times stronger than the earth's. That stimulates your brain's protons to align themselves. Then we shoot radio waves into you, which knocks the protons out of alignment. They then realign themselves, sending out radio signals we record on the scanner. The computer reads the signals and makes a series of detailed cross-sections of the layers of tissue. Tom looks at the machine, then back at her.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Can I have another Valium?

dialogues.speaker: A FEW MINUTES LATER,
dialogues.text: Tom lies down on the "tongue." The Nurses wrap sheets aro his arms and tuck them in under his body, immobilizing th He looks at one of them questioningly.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: So your arms don't touch the sides of the machine.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: That would be bad? She smiles and nods. The other Nurse puts a white cloth o his hair.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE 2
dialogues.text: Your party hat. He tries to smile, but he is unnerved. Elizabeth leans in staring down at Tom.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: It's so nice you and Maggie finally came to see me at work.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE CONTROL ROOM,
dialogues.text: a Technician hits a series of switches.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE MRI ROOM,
dialogues.text: the tongue starts to move, sliding into the tunnel. Tom l still, staring upward as he is pulled inside, like a corp a drawer sliding back into the wall of the morgue.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE MACHINE,
dialogues.text: it's only about two feet across, and less from top to bot Tom blinks, staring up at the ceiling as the tongue comes stop. It's incredibly claustrophobic.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Kinda hot in the coffin. ELIZABETH'S VOICE comes blaring out of speakers mounted o either side of the tunnel.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Yo, hey, hey, woah, I'm right here. Can you turn it down a little bit?

dialogues.speaker: IN THE CONTROL ROOM,
dialogues.text: Elizabeth leans back from a microphone and turns to a Technician.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Go ahead. The Technician enters some commands on a keyboard.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE MRI ROOM,
dialogues.text: the giant "hammers" that are contained in the cylinders t surround the tunnel start to move, slowly at first.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE CONTROL ROOM,
dialogues.text: Elizabeth turns to Maggie. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Did he bring any music?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, right here. She hands him a cassette. Elizabeth puts it into a tape d and pushes "play."

dialogues.speaker: IN THE MRI ROOM,
dialogues.text: the hammers pick up speed, and these things move. It gets noisy fast.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE TUNNEL,
dialogues.text: Tom's eyes widen. The hammers whip faster. Their POUNDING tremendous. Tom's music starts playing from the speakers. It's The Doors, "People Are Strange." The hammers whip faster. Elizabeth was right, it's good t music is loud, because the sound coming from the hammers deafening, like gunshots going off all around his head.

dialogues.speaker: HOUR OR SO.
dialogues.text: Tom, in spite of himself, bursts out laughing.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE CONTROL ROOM,
dialogues.text: they can hear the thundering hammers, the blaring music, above it all, Tom's crazy kind of laughter. Elizabeth looks at Maggie.

dialogues.speaker: INT CONTROL ROOM DAY
dialogues.text: Three electronic screens, two red and one whitish-blue, display various cross-sections of Tom's brain. Graphs and columns of numbers are listed alongside.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: No tumors, no growths, no scars or lesions, no intrusions or damaged tissue of any kind. Except for one tiny abnormality, your brain anatomy is textbook. Physically, anyway. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: What abnormality?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Well, it's so insignificant it's hardly worth mentioning. She leans forward to one of the screens and points to a s on a cross-section. ELIZABETH (cont' d) It's the parietal lobe. Here. There's a slight distension, just the tiniest bulge here in the arc of the crescent. That's uncommon.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: How uncommon?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: One in a half million, maybe, it doesn't really have a name. But it isn't consequential. Wouldn't have any effect on cognitive processes.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Great. There's nothing wrong with me, I gotta get back to work. (stands and shakes hands) Thank you for everything, Elizabeth, I owe you a giant one, hey, you think I can get some of that Valium to go? Elizabeth scowls at him. TOM (cont' d) Worth a try. Take care, say hi to Michael. (to Maggie) I'll pick up Jake, I told him I'd take him to the Pier tonight. He heads for the door, eager to get the hell out of there Maggie lingers, looking at Elizabeth, hopeful.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: There's really nothing wrong with him? Nothing at all?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Maggie. I said nothing physical.

dialogues.speaker: INT BEDROOM DAY
dialogues.text: Maggie is in the bedroom, cleaning up. She picks up Tom's pair of jeans from the floor and folds them over one arm. Something THUNKS to the floor. She picks it up. It's the butterfly knife, the one he took from Duane. She stares at it, fascinated and frightened. She lets it drop open. There is dried blood on the blade. Gingerly, she closes it again. She opens a drawer and put in, then thinks better of that. She takes it out again, l for a place to put it. She drops it in her purse and zips it shut. She'll deal w it later.

dialogues.speaker: EXT NAVY PIER NIGHT
dialogues.text: Navy Pier is an amusement park/shopping mall built on a p jutting out into Lake Michigan. It's a nice night, the pi is crowded, just enough urban edge to be interesting. A figure bobs along above the crowd -- Jake, sitting on Tom shoulders. They stop and join a CROWD watching a JUGGLER, good one, keeps five burning pins in the air. Jake suddenly looks up, confused by something. He stares the juggler, through the flames. Behind the juggler, a UNIFORMED COP is staring at the little boy -- it's the sa Cop who was parked outside their house earlier. Jake star back, the flaming pins flying up between them. Tom moves on, his boy still on his shoulders. The Cop tur and watches them go. Jake turns, looking back over his shoulder at the Cop. The Cop raises a hand and waves. Jak just stares.

dialogues.speaker: AT A TOY STORE,
dialogues.text: there is an elaborate model train set on display in the window.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Daddy, look!

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Woah, check it out. He stops, helps Jake down off his shoulders. Jake presses right up against the glass, staring at the train as it ci the track. Tom squats, admiring it with him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BEHIND THEM,
dialogues.text: the Cop is still watching them. He walks closer, stops on about ten feet away, staring. Tom glances up, sees him, thinks nothing of it. The 'op steps closer.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE. WINDOW,
dialogues.text: Tom sees the reflection of the Cop. Closer now, staring. turns and smiles, tight-lipped. He recognizes him from th other day. The Cop smiles back, doesn't go away.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (to Jake) Hey, look at that one! He carries Jake to the next window over, a different disp The Cop wanders closer. Tom finally turns to him, tense. TOM (cont' d) How ya doin'?

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Fine, fine. He's staring at Jake.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Is there a law against lookin' in the window now?

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Huh? Oh, no, `course not. I'm off duty. I live right up there.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: That's great. See ya later. He sweeps Jake up onto one hip and starts to walk away.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: It's even stronger in him than it is in you. Tom stops. Turns back.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: What? The Cop smiles and makes a face -- "you heard me." (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: TOM (cont' d) I don't know what you're talking about.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Jon't be afraid of it. Tom just star .s at the Cop, trembling slightly. The Cop forward. Fascinated, Tom does not back away. The Cop lowe his voice. COP (cont' d) You're not alone. Tom is too rattled to speak. COP (cont' d) You don't know about Cacophony yet? Tom shakes his head no. The Cop pulls out a note pad, scribbles something on a page, tears it out and holds it to Tom. COP (cont' d) Come next time. His hand shaking, Tom accepts the paper. The Cop reaches and tousles Jake's hair. COP (coast' d) Bye, Jake. The Cop turns and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Bye, Neil! The Cop looks back over his shoulder and smiles. Tom look his son as if he's never seen him before.

dialogues.speaker: INT JAKE'S ROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: Jake, fresh from a bath and in his pajamas, sits on the f of his room, playing with model cars, intent. He's HUMMIN soft tune to himself, the same one he hummed during his b in the opening. Tom and Maggie sit near him, staring at him. They're frea out. What have they got on their hands here?
